tit.e: Ukon no Tachibana, the mandarin orange tree of Ukon
Ukon no Tachibana, the mandarin orange tree of Ukon
tit.cmt: "the mandarin orange tree of Ukon"→次行に移動

sen.j: 右近橘（うこんのたちばな）は、平安京内裏紫宸殿からおりる南階の、紫宸殿から見て右にあったタチバナの樹。
sen.e: Ukon no Tachibana is the mandarin orange tree which existed at the right direction on the South floor down from the inner court ceremonial hall of Heian-kyo.
Ukon no Tachibana is a mandarin orange tree which existed on the right of the South floor down from the inner court ceremonial hall of Heian-kyo.

Ukon no Tachibana (the mandarin orange tree of Ukon) is a mandarin orange tree which existed on the right of the South floor down from the Shishin-den Hall (hall for state ceremonies) of the Imperial Palace in the Heian-kyo.
sen.cmt: the mandarin orange tree of Ukonを追加、「平安京内裏紫宸殿」の表記を修正

sen.e: It was facing Sakon no sakura, the cherry tree of Sakon.

sen.j: 『天暦御記』によれば、もとは秦河勝の宅にあったのを、内裏建造の際に紫宸殿があたかも宅の故地に相当するから、旧によってこれを植えたもので、天徳 (日本)年間（957年-961年）まであったという。
sen.e: According to "Tenryaku gyoki", the emperor's diary, the tree originally existed at the residence of HATA no Kawakatsu; it was replanted in the ceremonial hall when the inner court was built as the land was related to the residence, and it existed until the Tentoku era (957 to 961).

According to "Tenryaku gyoki", the emperor's diary, the tree originally existed at the residence of HATA no Kawakatsu; it was replanted in the ceremonial hall when the inner court was built as the land was related to the residence, and existed until the Tentoku era (957 to 961).

According to "Tenryaku Gyoki," the emperor's diary, the tree originally existed at the residence of HATA no Kawakatsu; it was replanted in the Shishin-den Hall when the Imperial Palace was built as the land was related to the residence, and existed until the Tentoku era (957 to 961).
sen.cmt: Tenryaku Gyokiとし、カンマの位置を移動、ceremonial hall→Shishin-den Hall、the inner court→the Imperial Palaceとしました。

sen.j: 『日本紀略』によれば、天徳3年（959年）12月7日あらたに橘樹1本、高さ1丈2尺を植え替え、これは弾正尹親王東三条殿の樹で、勅命によった。
sen.e: According to "Nihongi ryaku", the history book, a new mandarin orange tree with the height of 12 feet was transplanted on December 7, 959; it was the tree of Prince Higashi-Sanjo, Danjonokami, Governor of the Impeachment Office, and it was under the Emperor's ordinance.

According to "Nihongi ryaku", the history book, a new mandarin orange tree having a height of 12 feet was transplanted on December 7, 959; it was the tree of Prince Higashi-Sanjo, Danjonokami, Governor of the Impeachment Office, and it was planted under the Emperor's ordinance.

According to "Nihon Kiryaku" (the Abstracted Records of Japan), a new mandarin orange tree having a height of 12 feet was transplanted on December 7, 959; it was the tree of Prince Higashi-Sanjo, Danjonokami, Governor of the Impeachment Office, and it was planted under the Emperor's ordinance.
sen.cmt: 『日本紀略』(にほんきりゃく)の表記、補足を修正 (参照: http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/148195/m0u/)

sen.j: のちに、皇居の炎上その他でしばしば植え替えが行なわれたが、里内裏のさいにもまたこれを植え替える例となった。
sen.e: Later, the tree was transplanted sometimes for some reasons including fire at the Imperial Palace; it was also transplanted at the off-court palace.
Later, the tree was sometimes transplanted due to reasons including a fire at the Imperial Palace; it was also transplanted to the off-court palace.
Later, the tree was sometimes transplanted due to reasons including a fire at the Imperial Palace; it was also transplanted to the temporary imperial residence.
sen.cmt: the off-court palace→the temporary imperial residenceとしました。(参照: http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=7Eunlt5YbXcC&pg=PA46&dq=satodairi&lr=&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=satodairi&f=false)

sen.j: 橘を植えるのは、河勝宅地の縁だけではなくて、橘が古くからトキジクノカクノコノミといわれ、その葉が寒暖の別なく常に生い茂り栄えるから、長寿瑞祥の樹として珍重されたからでもあるという。
sen.e: A mandarin orange tree was transplanted not only for the relation with Kawakatsu; with the name of "Tokijikuno Kakuno-konomi", an ever-shining fruit, it was treated as a symbol of long life and auspiciousness since old times because of its dense leaves regardless of difference in temperature.
